title: SA firm on renewables target | Perth Now
text:
SA firm on renewables target Tim Dornin, Australian Associated Press February 21, 2017 3:43pm 
South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill has doubled-down on the state's ambitious renewable energy target as the debate over Australia's energy future continues. 
The government is working on a plan to intervene in the electricity market to ensure the state has a reliable supply after heatwave conditions forced power shedding across Adelaide and some regional centres two weeks ago. 
Mr Weatherill says details of the government plan will be revealed soon but insists renewables will be at the heart of its strategy as the state moves to a target of 50 per cent renewables by 2025. 
"We're doing this because it's good for business, it's good for jobs and it's also good for the affordability, the reliability and the cleanliness of our energy system," the premier told reporters on Tuesday. 
"We are doubling down on our commitment to renewable energy. 
"It's creating thousands of jobs, it's cleaning up our energy system, it's going to give us a reliable and affordable form of energy for the future and it will be at the heart of our energy plan." 
The government said previously it was exploring all options to ensure reliable power in South Australia after 90,000 consumers were cut off on February 8 when the Australian Energy Market Operator ordered load shedding to ease demand on the national electricity network. 
That could include the promotion of solar thermal generation, battery storage systems and other measures such as pumped-hydro power generation. 
On Tuesday Energy Australia revealed it was looking at building a pumped-hydro generator in SA's Spencer Gulf, near industry hotspots Whyalla, Port Augusta and Port Pirie. 
The federal government has offered the company $450,000 in taxpayer funds to help with a feasibility study and, if viable, the plant could be running by the summer of 2020. 
Mr Weatherill said companies were "beating down our doors" promoting renewable energy projects and no one was coming to the government talking about building a new coal-fired power station. 
"People that are talking about coal are talking about the past. We're talking about renewable energy which is the future," he said.
